bibl.title: Letter from the Chief Quarantine Officer to [Rupert Blue], February 13, 1916

div1.p: The Chief Quarantine Officer relates information on a case of yellow fever and notes disagreement over the diagnosis.

div1.head: Letter from the Chief Quarantine Officer to [Rupert Blue], February 13, 1916
div1.opener:
Reporting facts regarding illness and
death of Service patient.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Q. S.
San Juan, Porto Rico, February 13, 1916.
The Surgeon-General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I have the honor to report the following facts in
the case of J. M. Croll, a patient of the Public Health
Service, at the Military Hospital, San Juan, Porto Rico,
and certified by Major Dutcher, M. C., U. S. A., to have died
from yellow fever.

J. M. Croll, aged 58, native of Scotland, purser
on S/S. “Mariana.”

Previous history:- Had been in Scotland some months
during which time he had suffered from an attack of asthma
or pneumonia. Returning to New York, he shipped in a few
days as purser on the S/S. “Mariana.” His health at that
time was not good but improved during the voyage to Galves-
ton and Port Arthur, Texas. Three days after leaving Port
Arthur and four days before arriving at San Juan, he became
worse complaining of dyspnea, vomiting, precardial pain and
diarrhea.

On arrival at San Juan he was immediately seen by
- 2 -
Acting Assistant Surgeon del Valle, who examined hin on board.
The examination was unsatisfactory owing to the noise and
confusion of unloading cargo, but Dr. del Valle made a ten-
tative diagnosis of Bright's disease with dilatation of the
heart and symptomatic asthma. The man was evidently very
sick and was sent at once to the Military Hospital where he
was attended by the medical officers of that hospital.

The principal symptoms noted on the clinical history
furnished me by Major Dutcher, word:- Dyspnea, vomiting of
clear fluid, weak pulse. Heart sounds weak and distant. Signs
of fluid in lungs. Pain and tenderness in upper abdomen.
Collapse two or three times daily while under treatment.
Temperature subnormal between 98. and 94. F until two days
before death when it rose to 99. F, and remained about that
degree. Pulse averaged between 80 and 90 until three days
before death, when it dropped to an average of 70 for two days,
rising again to 90 the day before death. During the last two days
of illness he vomited sanguinous and tarry appearing vomit.
Urine was examined twice. On February 3rd, it showed a trace of
albumin and a slightly larger amount on February 4th. On Feb-
ruary 4th, the sclera showed jaundice which became noticeable
on the skin before death.

He died at 3.45 A.M., February 8, 1916, with symptoms
indicating excessive edema of the lung. A copy of the report
of autopsy is herewith enclosed.

In blood smears taken before death, and in smears from
various organs, taken at autopsy, were certain bodies which
Major Dutcher stated were paraplasma flavigenum, or a similar
parasite, and which he showed me stating that it was the cause
of yellow fever. These bodies were elongated, slightly oval,
with roundish or squarish ends from about five to fifteen
microns in length, and from approximately two to three microns
in width. These measurements I estimated roughly by comparison
with the red corpustles from the same specimen. These bodies
were transversely segmented, usually into four parts. They
did not correspond, except very remotely to descriptions and
illustrations that I have seen of Seidelin's paraplasma
flavigenum, but I have not at my command a complete literature
on this organism.

The New York & Porto Rico Steamship Co., claimed the
body and had it prepared for shipment to the United States.
The death certificate signed by Major Dutcher gave yellow
fever as the cause of death, the only diagnosis which Major
Dutcher stated he could concientiously give.

In issuing the shipping permit Dr. W. F. Lippitt,
Director of Sanitation, stated that he had investigated the
case and did not agree to the diagnosis of yellow fever. It
is customary when a body is to be shipped from this port,
for this office to issue a similar certificate certifying that
it had been properly embalmed and shipped in accordance with
the U. S. Quarantine Regulations. In issuing this certificate
I also stated that I disagreed with the diagnosis of yellow
- 4 -
fever.

Inasmuch as the death certificate accompanied the
body to New York it was thoughed thought advisable by both Dr. Lippitt
and myself to state our disagreement with the diagnosis in
order that the quarantine officer at New York should under-
stand the character of the case, and because we did not feel
justified in altering the diagnosis on an official death
certificate, over the signature of another physician. The body
was shipped on the S/S. “Carolina” on February 9, 1916,

I had heard nothing about this case until the under-
taker came to the office for the shipping permit, and was
unable to get the above facts in time to make a report of the
case in the mail of February 9th.
div1.closer: Respectfully, Surgeon, Chief Quarantine Officer. WWK/CVFD.
